abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Background</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Single-variant associations with age-related macular degeneration (AMD), one of the most prevalent causes of irreversible vision loss worldwide, have been studied extensively. However, because of a lack of refinement of these associations, there remains considerable ambiguity regarding what constitutes genetic risk and/or protection for this disease, and how genetic combinations affect this risk. In this study, we consider the two most common and strongly AMD-associated loci, the <jats:italic>CFH-CFHR5</jats:italic> region on chromosome 1q32  (Chr1 locus) and <jats:italic>ARMS2/HTRA1</jats:italic> gene on chromosome 10q26  (Chr10 locus).</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
                <jats:p>By refining associations within the <jats:italic>CFH-CFHR5</jats:italic> locus, we show that all genetic protection against the development of AMD in this region is described by the combination of the amino acid-altering variant <jats:italic>CFH</jats:italic> I62V (rs800292) and genetic deletion of <jats:italic>CFHR3/1</jats:italic>. Haplotypes based on <jats:italic>CFH</jats:italic> I62V, a <jats:italic>CFHR3/1</jats:italic> deletion tagging SNP and the risk variant <jats:italic>CFH</jats:italic> Y402H are associated with either risk, protection or neutrality for AMD and capture more than 99% of control- and case-associated chromosomes. We find that genetic combinations of <jats:italic>CFH-CFHR5</jats:italic> haplotypes (diplotypes) strongly influence AMD susceptibility and that individuals with risk/protective diplotypes are substantially protected against the development of disease. Finally, we demonstrate that AMD risk in the <jats:italic>ARMS2/HTRA1</jats:italic> locus is also mitigated by combinations of <jats:italic>CFH-CFHR5</jats:italic> haplotypes, with Chr10 risk variants essentially neutralized by protective <jats:italic>CFH</jats:italic>-<jats:italic>CFHR5</jats:italic> haplotypes.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Conclusions</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Our study highlights the importance of considering protective <jats:italic>CFH-CFHR5</jats:italic> haplotypes when assessing genetic susceptibility for AMD. It establishes a framework that describes the full spectrum of AMD susceptibility using an optimal set of single-nucleotide polymorphisms with known functional consequences. It also indicates that protective or preventive complement-directed therapies targeting AMD driven by <jats:italic>CFH-CFHR5</jats:italic> risk haplotypes may also be effective when AMD is driven by <jats:italic>ARMS2/HTRA1</jats:italic> risk variants.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>

group.label: Ethics approval and consent to participate
group.name: EthicsHeading

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The study adhered to the tenets of the Declaration of Helsinki and was approved by the Institutional Review Boards of the University of Utah and University of Iowa, where all research was performed. All participants provided informed written research consent at the time of recruitment.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: All participants provided informed written research consent at the time of recruitment, which covered publication of said research.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: GSH is a shareholder, consultant and co-founder of Voyant Biotherapeutics, LLC. GSH, CP, BLW and BTR are inventors on patents and patent applications owned by the University of Utah. JLH is the spouse of GSH. None of the other authors have any relevant proprietary interests.

publisher: Springer Science and Business Media LLC
